Description: Rim and body sherd of Nile silt ware pottery bowl or mug (?); whitish slip (mostly worn); interior: trace of red-fired band at top, reserved below; top of rim glazed; exterior reserved with trace of wide red band.
Curator's comments: For the shape of this small vessel, Schlotzhauer cites as parallels Hayes' group of unclassified East Greek footed bowls (Boardman and Hayes 1966, p. 54, fig. 27, no. 870) and Stibbe's Laconian Group H kalyx kraters (Stibbe 1994, 55, 156-7). The shape is also remotely reminiscent of Hera mugs and other Ionian mugs (see British Museum 1888,0601.401, 1888, 0601.402, 1888.0601.403, and 1888,0601.405; cf. also Boston 88.930;Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.227.1899 and Boston 88.930). However, the relatively wide and flat rim is unusual for a drinking vessel. For the decoration Schlotzhauer compares Cypriot bichrome pottery.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer & Villing 2006 / East Greek Pottery from Naukratis: The Current State of Research (p. 62, p. 68, note 107)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IA.27) (phase 3)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 176, NAU 148, pl. 32 h-i)
